author: pam

review: Setup was a no brainer. It required an update immediately so it did take about 15 minutes to have it in action but the process was very simple.The image quality (movies and games) is excellent. I've tried several movies from Amazon Prime and they look and sound nearly Blu Ray quality as far as I can tell.Navigation is very straightforward and it's generally easy to find anything you're looking for. Installation of games and apps goes very smoothly and generally pretty quickly.The remote works very well. I haven't played with the voice search feature much yet, but when I have tried it, it worked well. The buttons on the remote are well thought out and I prefer it to the Apple TV remote.What I don't like is how Amazon has made it so the"Prime" content is mixed with the "For Pay" content, with no easy way to just see what is ONLY "Prime" content. This is obviously made to divert you into buying more non Prime content...Amazon, please give us a CLEAR way to view "Prime Only" if that's what we want. I know we can voice search for anything... and that's great, but sometimes we just want to "Go Fishing" and would like to fish in the "Prime" pond only. This is a pretty big deal when you compare this to competing (Think ROKU) products that let you do just that.Hard to believe your competition does a better job with presenting your own content than you do. Maybe an update in the near future will "Fix" this.

review: I think this is a great start for Fire TV. It is a lot more polished than I would expect from a first gen device. I've owned a Roku 3 (which I dearly love) and Apple TV. I think I will be retiring my Roku.The setup was very quick, painless, and since I have a good high speed Wi-Fi connection the update took only a minute or two and it was all ready.Here's what I like, and then a few things that I hope to see in the future.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------1. Speed - it's really fast, and can stream 1080p content immediately. The menus are snappy and when I connected to Plex the dashboard populated almost instantaneously, which is great.2. Convenience - The voice search is pretty accurate and a refreshing differentiation compared to other streaming devices. It's just a whole lot more convenient than typing on the keyboard.3. Availability of major apps - some good apps (this is also an area of improvement). I got all I wanted as I tend to spend 90% of my time on Plex, Netflix and Prime. Maybe Vevo sometimes. The Youtube interface is terrible. HBP Go is the major missing channel but it's coming this year as we've seen the announcements.What I'd like to see soon---------------------------------1. Integrated voice search across all apps - when I search for a movie I'd like it to pull results from Amazon, Netflix, Plex, and whatever app supports voice search. I read recently that Amazon is opening the SDK for 3rd party to build voice search support, let's all hope it happens quickly.2. Better prime differentiation - right now prime results are mixed with the rest. C'mon Amazon, for a company of your customer orientation it seems improper to try to trick us into buying stuff. Allow for clear Prime differentiation / filtering.3. Voice commands - right now the voice search is a keyword search. For e.g. If I say  "Netflix", it shows Netflix as a result. And then I click, choose Netflix app to launch. What should happen is allow for control. For e.g. "Launch Netflix" should launch the app. "Start good wife" should start the latest episode of Good wife from the watchlist. That's when it begins to get really convenient.Since the hardware is robust, most of these features are software updates and should happen as time goes by. If they deliver on the voice innovations and cross-app integration, we have a winner! The 4* reflects my view that this is a great start with some holes.(I have no interest in games so no review on that aspect. I'm looking forward to the Kindle FreeTime for kids and will update once  I see how that works)
